elements that hasn't any even digit.

Note: Returned vector should be sorted in increasing order.

For example:
>>> unique_digit({15, 33, 1422, 1})
{1, 15, 33}
>>> unique_digit({152, 323, 1422, 10})

#include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
#include<algorithm>
using namespace std;
vector<int> unique_digit(vector<int> x){
    vector<int> y;
    sort(x.begin(), x.end());
    for(int i=0;i<x.size();i++){
        if(!(x[i]%2)){
            y.push_back(x[i]);
        }
    }
    return y;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Given a vector of integers, sort the integers that are between 1 and 9 inclusive,
reverse the resulting vector, and then replace each digit by its corresponding name from
"One", "Two", "Three", "Four", "Five", "Six", "Seven", "Eight", "Nine".

For example:
  arr = {2, 1, 1, 4, 5, 8, 2, 3}   
        -> sort arr -> {1, 1, 2, 2, 3, 4, 5, 8} 
        -> reverse arr -> {8, 5, 4, 3, 2, 2, 1, 1}
  return {"Eight", "Five", "Four", "Three", "Two", "Two", "One", "One"}

  If the vector is empty, return an empty vector:
  arr = {}
  return {}

  If the vector has any strange number ignore it:
  arr = {1, -1, 55} 
        -> sort arr -> {-1, 1, 55}
        -> reverse arr -> {55, 1, -1}
  return = {"One"}
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
#include<string>
#include<map>
#include<algorithm>
using namespace std;
vector<string> by_length(vector<int> arr){
    map<int,string> m;
    for(int i=0;i<arr.size();i++){
        if(m[i]==NULL){
            m[i]=arr[i];
        }else{
            m[i]=m[i].concat(arr[i]);
        }
    }
    vector<string> res;
    for(int i=0;i<arr.size();i++){
        if(m[i]!=NULL){
            res.push_back(m[i].c_str());
        }
    }
    return res;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Create a function that takes integers, floats, or strings representing
real numbers, and returns the larger variable in its given variable type.
Return "None" if the values are equal.
Note: If a real number is represented as a string, the floating point might be. or,

comparing_one(1, 2.5) ➞ 2.5
comparing_one(1, "2,3") ➞ "2,3"
comparing_one("5,1", "6") ➞ "6"
comparing_one("1", 1) ➞ "None"
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<string>
#include<algorithm>
#include<boost/any.hpp>
using namespace std;
boost::any comparing_one(boost::any a,boost::any b){
    string str1 = boost::any_cast<string>(boost::any_cast<boost::any>(a));
    string str2 = boost::any_cast<string>(boost::any_cast<boost::any>(b));
    if(str1 == str2){
        return a;
    }
    else{
        return b;
    }
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Evaluate whether the given number n can be written as the sum of exactly 4 positive even numbers
Example
is_equal_to_summing_even(4) == false
is_equal_to_summing_even(6) == false
is_equal_to_summing_even(8) == true
*/
#include<stdio.h>
using namespace std;
bool is_equal_to_summing_even(int n){
    int sum = 0;
    for(int i = 1; i <= n; i++){
        if((i % 2) == 0){
            sum += i;
        }
    }
    return sum == 4;
}

double poly(vector<double> xs, double x){
    /* 
    Evaluates polynomial with coefficients xs at point x. return xs[0] + xs[1] * x + xs[1] * x^2 +.... xs[n] * x^n 
    */
    double sum=0;
    int i;
    for (i=0;i<xs.size();i++)
    {
        sum+=xs[i]*pow(x,i);
    }
    return sum;
}

double find_zero(vector<double> xs){
    /*
    xs are coefficients of a polynomial. find_zero find x such that poly(x) = 0. find_zero returns only only zero point, even if there are many. 
    Moreover, find_zero only takes list xs having even number of coefficients and largest non zero coefficient as it guarantees a solution.
    >>> round(find_zero([1, 2]), 2) #f(x) = 1 + 2x 
    -0.5 
    >>> round(find_zero([-6, 11, -6, 1]), 2) # (x - 1) * (x - 2) * (x - 3) = -6 + 11x - 6x^2 + x^3 
    1.0
    */
    double sum=0;
    double zero=0;
    int i;
    for (i=0;i<xs.size();i++)
    {
        if (xs[i]!=0)
        {
            sum+=xs[i]*xs[i];
        }
        else
        {
            zero=i;
        }
    }
    return zero;
}

    double sum=0;
    double one=0;

            sum+=xs[i]*xs[i];

        }
    }

}

<|endoftext|>/*
Return sorted unique elements in a vector
>>> unique({5, 3, 5, 2, 3, 3, 9, 0, 123})
{0, 2, 3, 5, 9, 123}
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
#include<algorithm>
using namespace std;
vector<int> unique(vector<int> l){
    sort(l.begin(), l.end());
    vector<int> u;
    for(int i = 0; i < l.size(); i++){
        if(!u.count(l[i])){
            u.push_back(l[i]);
        }
    }
    return u;
}

total_match({"4"}, {"1", "2", "3", "4", "5"}) ➞ {"4"}

#include<stdio.h>

vector<string> total_match(vector<string> lst1,vector<string> lst2){

}

The function should return false is the given map is empty.
Examples:
check_map_case({{"a","apple"}, {"b","banana"}}) should return true.
check_map_case({{"a","apple"}, {"A","banana"}, {"B","banana"}}) should return false.
check_map_case({{"a","apple"}, {"8","banana"}, {"a","apple"}}) should return false.
check_map_case({{"Name","John"}, {"Age","36"}, {"City","Houston"}}) should return false.
check_map_case({{"STATE","NC"}, {"ZIP","12345"} }) should return true.

#include<string>
#include<map>

    map<string,string>::iterator it;

        if(!(*it).empty()){
            if(toupper(*it).compare(toupper(*dict.begin())) == 0){
                return false;
            }
        }
    }
    return true;
}
